One presumes that most gamers interested in pinball have some degree of experience, so this review focuses on what makes Zaccaria Pinball what it is, and specific information on each table posted seperately. What all potential players DO need to be aware of is that these tables were produced 30 to 40 years ago as physical pinball tables by Italian designers, so few of them have been seen before in North America. This review will hopefully receive revising as needed.(A listing of far more information, as well as details on each and every individual table, will be posted on the Zaccaria Pinball discussion page. Thank you.)http://steamcommunity.com/app/444930/discussions/0/358415206080779382/http://steamcommunity.com/app/444930/discussions/0/358415206080766569/ZACCARIA PINBALL – CHANGES TODAY’S PLAYERS SHOULD TAKE NOTE OFLane Lights/NudgingAll of the Zaccaria Pinball tables came right at the cusp of the “flipper-changed lane lights” era, so none of them have this (now) long standard feature. This absence strongly changes the dynamic of the game, requiring the ball to traverse lanes far more times (for the average player), requiring more aiming skill and a different strategy. But overall, older tables will generally require increased skill.One aspect of the increased skill, as well as the lack of control over lane lights, is an increased benefit to nudging. This player is required by circumstance to play one-handed, with a controller. As it is far more difficult to accomplish substantially more actions with what amounts to just two fingers, I am unable to specifically comment on the effect, need, use, or advantages to nudging in Zaccaria Pinball. Others will be more qualified, and no doubt will be anxious to help. It should be safe to say that nudging is substantially more crucial in Zaccaria Pinball than in newer tables, or tables that originated in digital form.Sound EffectsThe original Zaccaria Pinball tables came at a time when sound was finding a more significant place in pinball. As such, even ZP tables that might be expected to have great sound, such as circus or military themed tables, may have almost no sound at all. And the several tables that bravely use voice acting may present largely unintelligible phrases. But a few of the later tables really do have great sound effects, and considering historical context, weak sound should not be considered a negative.The Dreaded OutlaneNow for Zaccaria Pinball’s dark little secret. Numerous tables present a strong argument of having been specifically designed to feed balls into outlanes. Many, or most (or all) players will have games where every ball leaves through an outlane, never having been touched by flipper. And they will be on the same tables. (This reviewer had one table quickly direct nine out of nine balls to outlanes during testing. But this extreme case may certainly be an anomaly.) Seeing the ball “ladder” up the slingshots into an outlane is one of the most distressing actions in pinball…and in Zaccaria Pinball is far from rare on several tables. Experienced players will see all the design elements, such as lowered outlane barriers and slingshot strength and angles, which encourage gravity to consistently act contrary to the design of a long-play table (and the wishes of many players.) Safe to say, identifying those tables by name is neither prudent nor necessary, but they are the minority and they do not attempt to hide. Please keep in mind that these tables were designed to be coin operated, so games of extreme length were not always in the best financial interest.CamerasWhile Zaccaria Pinball has wonderful control over camera views, there may still be some issues to be considered. This reviewer has been playing computer pinball in portrait mode exclusively for well over a year, and Zaccaria Pinball makes this incredibly easy. Simply set your monitor to portrait view through Windows, Zaccaria Pinball takes care of everything else instantly and automatically. But what this player found on two i7, Windows 10 laptops is that by using any of the seven default ZP camera views, left and right edges of all table were lost to the degree that outlanes weren’t even a trace on the screen, much less the outlane flippers that can be so vital. But the problem may be the solution: camera options.It appears that Cameras 1 -3 may be fixed, but 4 – 7 are easily modifiable. Since option changes appear onscreen as they’re chosen, select the camera in that four camera range that shows the view you prefer. Then change the FOV (field of view) setting to something around 60%. This should allow you to see the entire table, and further tweaking may provide even better results. (This basically emulates Fly Cam, which, if one might think adequate to SHOW the table, would be adequate to PLAY the table.)Options!!!	It may be safe to unequivocally state that there has NEVER been a pinball game that allowed the player such a remarkable degree of control. There are far too many selections to go into in detail, but the scope should be indicated. For example, this player likes to play Zaccaria Pinball with the background sounds of a tropical island, playing in the early evening during a thunderstorm on a tables that looks as if they’ve been played for many years and not cleaned (much like this player, in fact.) So that’s EXACTLY what I do. Or a more urban player may wish to play as if in an arcade (the default) or an airport, on a brand new, spotlessly clean table, sunny mid-afternoon. Players may change the ball to granite or glass. Or make the sound of the rolling ball or flipper strike louder or quieter. Changes can also be made to physics, but unless you have selected USER as game mode, they will have no effect. USER mode has its own leaderboard, but this player’s single experience was that the leaderboard wasn’t populated. (What would be the point of a leaderboard of miscellaneous and widely varied laws of physics? A 1% slant generated score compared to a 99% slant generated score?)Experiment with options. Early Access Review
								Speaking as a pinball table owner, I can say Zaccaria Pinball is quite an accurate simulation, although not absolutely perfect. Some aspects of the physics of the tables are being adjusted on an ongoing basis during early access, but the game is already in a state that I would say is virtually complete. The tables themselves are authentic tables manufactured by Zaccaria, an Italian company which existed between 1974 and 1988. On first sight they don't match up visually to later tables, particularly those of U.S. manufacturers who often market their tables with tie-ins from Hollywood movies. However, the Zaccaria tables do have a beauty of their own. Their characteristic style is representative of the popular cartoon art of the era in which they were made. Being quite old, the tables have fewer toys, ramps and rails on the play surface than you would typically find on tables from the late 1980s onwards. They also lack the l.e.d. display fields and more complicated rule-sets typical of later tables.For anyone too young to have encountered these tables for real, Zaccaria Pinball (the video game) is offering the experience of playing historically accurate and still highly enjoyable pinball tables on your computer (or other device), which is practically the only way these days.In terms of playability, these older types of tables can be less forgiving, and due to the simpler rule-sets, the games aren't as engrossing as many you find in Farsight Studios' The Pinball Arcade. However, you have exactly the same issue with the older electro-mechanical and early solid-state tables in The Pinball Arcade.Pixel Magic, the makers of Zaccaria Pinball (the video game) have done a superb job of rendering the game and it looks amazing. The only exception is the back glass, which looks a bit strange close up. The under-surface lighting, reflections from the table glass, and even optional fingerprints and scratches help to create the illusion of playing something well used and real. While it might not provide quite the buzz of some other contemporary pinball video games, it achieves a higher degree of authenticity and is still still very enjoyable. I have no hesitation in recommending Zaccaria Pinball.

If you play a table and think "all pinball is the same" or "you just whack balls around", you don't get it... yet. You should give it an honest try before judging, because pinball will blow your mind if you give it a chance. Have a friend explain it, or watch some videos about the magic that is...P I N B A L LFOR PINBALL VETS:Zaccaria supplies some European recreations that most of the American pinball audience has never seen. They're primarily in the EM/SS eras, are absolutely brutal, but always make you want to play just ooooone more game. Can't say I'd ever pop quarters into these machines (too brutal for my skills), but digitally: I'm hooked!Things to NOT expect:- Fancy DMDs (not including "remixed" tables)- Crazy lightshows- Complex rulesets/missions (not including "remixed" tables)- Music (for the most part, and not including "remixed" tables)Things TO expect:- Fantastic and rarely experienced EM/SS table recreations- Incredibly hard-yet-satisfying flows- A much higher (and thus more satisfying) learning curve than standard American tables- Being forced to become a master of your flippers and ball... there are no random flipping points to be had hereUNIQUE Pros:- !!!! COMPLETE CUSTOMIZATION (camera, lights, physics, reflections, table dirt/scratches, etc)... THE #1 pro to this suite !!!- Custom "Extra Game" modes/challenges not available on the original tables- The best graphics outside of pre-rendered applications (Pro Pinball Ultra)- "Remixed" tables that turn the old school EM/SS tables into DMD era titles- A *ton* of achievementsIf you play TPA: this has the customization you've been wanting and could only get from 3rd party sources (because Stern is too afraid of letting digital be an interactive catalogue or "lower class" market, the fools)If you play FX2: this has the non-IP-oriented tables and environment customization you've been cravingWhat's missing (at the moment)?- True pincab support (seemingly on the docket, but we'll see). The game works fine on my pincab, buuuut you won't utilize multiple monitors or a DMD. Still, *fantastic* to play on my full-scale pincab... it can only get better from here :)- Plenty of wishlist items, but as-is it's something I have chosen to play far more often than the other suites

								I've been playing computer pinball simulations since David's Midnight Magic and Pinball Construction Set on my Commodore 64. Bought just about anything that claims to be pinball, including a few truly execrable titles. This is definitely among the best. The improvements and responsiveness of the developers to constructive criticism and bug reports has been quite gratifying. If you like pinball at all, consider buying the whole Gold Membership DLC. There's a tremendous value there and the achievement implementation is quite compelling, with novel modes such as Lamp Hunter and 90-second challenges. Some less-happy reviews have been frustrated that some of the customization options are available only through DLC (Bronze Membership). Just go ahead and get the Gold membership which has both the first 30+ tables and the customization options. If you're used to the more modern, deep-rule games seen in simulations such as Pinball Arcade, you'll need to take a bit of time to get used to these. Some table designs are repetitive, but once you get tuned in to the table, the subtle differences really make you think about how you're controlling the ball.  And if you prefer Pinball FX to Pinball Arcade, you might not like these tables at all. The Zaccaria tables are an older style with limited programming and very few novelties. Some ramps, second playfields; multiball is rare. The one modern remake table released so far (Shooting the Rapids 2016) is a strong first effort and is a good demo for the potential of their engine. It's not up to the standard of a table that you might get from a Stern, but it's definitely more than a re-skin, with interesting added features including a rotating bagatelle (on which the ball often gets stuck, so learn to nudge gently).

								If you like pinball but want to play something with a lil' different feel and look than the Bally, Williams, or Gottlieb games then Zaccaria Pinball might be what you're looking for.These games are generally much simpler than pins from other manufacturers, especially compared to what was being put out in the 80's and 90's by Bally, Williams, and Gottlieb, but that is just part of what makes them fun and enjoyable.  You can figure out what you have to do with any of these pins to ramp points quickly and then its all about getting the ball to do what you want to make it happen.The striking art, unusual layouts, and quirky sound effects somehow all come together to make these pins great.  At the time of this review the game is in Early Access status so maybe its a good idea to wait a bit while they finish tweaking things.  But so far the devs seem to be doing a great job at it (4 updates in just a few days!) and do respond from time to time in the forum to player's comments so I decided to give it a shot and buy in anyways.I play Pinball Arcade quite a bit and in comparison so far the game feels essentially complete to me.  Stability is actually better than Pinball Arcade at the moment!  (Farsight just did a update a day or so ago that changes the menus and some other things and now Pinball Arcade locks up on me fairly regularly  :/  )  Only real issues IMO right now is the ball physics (I think it needs to be heavier to be more realistic), ball-on-flipper handling (ball suddenly "acts" heavier when it touches a flipper), and speed on the playfield (too fast right now!  especially for their 70's era EM machines) and some other minor tweaks like slingshot sensitivity.  There are options in the menus to tweak some stuff to help there already but I just can't seem to get it right with them.  They do help though so things are hardly bad at all with the way the game plays right now either at default or with tweaked settings.  I'm sure they'll get worked out over time.  Or at least the devs will give users the option to tweak those things in a menu.  They already let you tweak almost everything else!  The sheer amount of adjustments you can make to the game are impressive and are an area where Zaccaria really has a leg up on Pinball Arcade already.  The way the menus are set up is also better too IMO, even after Pinball Arcade's recent update (though I will say PA's new menus are a step in the right direction).  They're very clear and intuitive to  use.  All in all I think for pinball enthusiasts this game is nearly a must buy.  Its nearly impossible to even find a Zaccaria pins in the real world anymore and typically they're in sad condition.  This game gives you the chance to play ALL of them in proper working order the way they should be played!If you're not much into pinball or have never tried it I think this game is still worth give it a go:  it is free to play 1 of the tables so you can see if its for you.  They're quick playing games that are easy to learn but hard to master and whimsical themes really lend themselves well to some casual gaming styles.  Give it a shot, you'll probably like it!Other info:  I bought the Gold version of this game with all the tables for about $40 which seems like the best deal overall since it had all the games.  I think there are some settings the Gold version has that the free version don't but none of them really are needed.  Its stuff like changing the ball materials and flipper colors according to the store page description.  Nice to have but IMO its more for enthusiasts who like to tweak everything just so.

								Simply put, this game is boss.Let's be honest here, every pinball collection on Steam has its flaws. Pinball FX has neat tables, but they're all fantasy tables that could never exist in real life and rely heavily on achieving table goals for enjoyment. The Pinball Arcade is full of real tables, but focuses on the more bombastic American releases, providing a lot of eye candy and fun tables but not a great overview of the basics and development of pinball over the years (something most collections suffer.) Most other collections are not only significantly smaller, but often feature less than inspired table designs or janky physics.Enter Zaccaria Pinball.I've never seen any of these tables in real life. I've never HEARD of any of them. I've never heard anyone so much as mention the company. These are not the most complicated tables you'll play, or the most unique in gameplay, but what they lack in those areas they make up for in presenting an excellent picture of the evolution of solid state pinball tables and provide arguably a more authentic "classic" pinball experience than the more complex (and, admittedly, arguably more important) titles featured in The Pinball Arcade.The artwork on these tables -- and in the game in general -- is gorgeous, a fantastic fusion of 70s/80s neon and graphic design with modern computing power. Tables even offer the option to provide dirt and aging to their surfaces, letting you recreate the feel of an older system rather than the prisitine look of a brand new table. The physics, as well, offer a great amount of options, allowing you to customize the feel to be more TPA or more FX2 depending on your preferences, and overall the collection feels great. Tables feature little in the way of music, but mechanics and sound effects sound great, and the horrible digitized speech you just KNOW matches the original samples only adds to the flavor.Interface is a mixxed bag, with an obvious leaning toward touch screen optimization on menus and large, unwieldy icons in place of what could have been far more elegant lists and drop-down menus, but it's usable, and feels better to navigate than the new TPA interface at least, if about equally unattractive.In short, Zaccaria is a great pinball game. The 80$ price tag feels a bit high, but at 2.00 a table it's cheaper than or on par with offerings from the game's nearest competitors, and at 1/2 off for the gold pack it's a steal.

								If you enjoy playing older-style pinball games - ones that are focused purely on scoring loads of points with a minimum of gimmicks and razzle-dazzle - you aren't going to find a better way to play than Zaccaria Pinball. While the more famous Pinball Arcade is host to all the licensed, fancy, crazy tables most people remember, Zaccaria's games are from the generation before that. Gameplay is fast, simple, and addicting. Drains are extremely frequent and sometimes seem downright unfair, due to how pinball games were designed in the 70s, but the brief nature of the games means it's very easy to get into a game and make a quick attempt at a high score, as opposed to the lengthy sessions you'd need to play a more modern machine. If you can stay in play on a Zaccaria machine for five minutes on three balls, you're doing well.What really makes this game worth my recommendation is the work that has been put into making it replayable. Quality of Life features are everywhere - a quick and easy restart, ways to sort the tables, the ability to try any table before you buy it, constant bugfixes and updates - I've been playing for less than a month and Magic Pixel has added two new game modes and two new tables in that time. Every game has TWELVE leaderboards, and with over forty games in the collection, that means you have over 480 leaderboards to compete on. The games themselves are hard and unforgiving, yes, but Magic Pixel has done everything possible to make them presentable to the modern player without actually changing them into something they aren't.If you play the free version (which includes Time Machine and free trials for all other tables except unlockables) and you enjoy it, I highly recommend the Gold Membership Bundle. It works out to just over a dollar per table, with the ability to unlock more tables, and is definitely the best value. The "remake" tables, sold separately from the bundles, attempt to bring Zaccaria into the modern era, which is good if you like both kinds of pinball and TPA and Zen aren't doing it for you, but are separate purchases. I can't comment on the VR DLC, because I don't use VR.In short:+ Free trial is generous and, as long as you don't touch the options, never gets pushy+ Beautiful graphics with faithfully, lovingly reproduced tables+ Fun, quick gameplay you can quickly restart if you mess up or get screwed over+ Tons of modes to play and leaderboards to compete on to increase replay value+ Updated frequently to fix bugs and add new content by developers who care (unlike Pinball Arcade which is ignoring months-old bug reports)+ Some of that new content is added for free, such as the "Story Mode" that went live in March 2017.+ Achievements actually mean something! You can unlock free tables by getting lots of achievements.- Having to pay for options is a little silly- The tables themselves tend to be "drain monsters" and some drains can be hard to swallow, so this game isn't for everyone- Unlike PBA, no background information is given about the games besides their original release date, even in the "Story Mode", which is more of an endurance challenge, not a story. If you want to learn about Zaccaria's history as a company, turn to Google.

								It seems to have all the functionality of Pinball FX 1 and 2. Theres less flash then the fx tables considering a lot of them are liscensed. FX seems to play and flow a bit smoother. Zaccaria has quite a bit of variety from the demos of the tables I play. Definitely some "cheap moments" where the ball flies out of bounds randomly, but I feel like thats just a part of pinball itself. The tables are styled after great classics, and some are direct remakes of real tables. Tables are also a bit cheaper due to the fact most of the tables aren't liscensed. The sound effects sound right, but sometimes they can be grating. Especially vocal samples. Overall it's a great game, and most of my complaints are finnicky. If you love pinball, and need something different from Pinball FX this will definitely work, and since it's early acess hopefully they will improve on any minor complaints people have.

								These tables are faithful reproductions of the actual pinball machines (You can go on Youtube to compare the game to the real thing).  The thing I notice about Zaccaria tables are that the original designers seemed to get lazy as some of the tables are very similar to one another and feature the same design elements.  A few of the tables are extremely frustrating because there is little to do, or the ball naturally funnels to the center of the table so that it goes right thru the center of the flippers everytime, or seems to find the outlane too often.  But I imagine that this is a flaw with the original table, not the video game itself.  I suggest you give it a try and only purchase the tables that you find enjoyable.
